body.p: A 39-year-old woman presented with palpitations and breathlessness, with a history of previous (2004) multiple traumatic fractures (right femur, pelvis, facial Lefort II).

On admission, she was tachypneic and the blood pressure was 110/600 mm Hg. No lower limb edema was present. A systolic murmur was heard at the periumbilical region and a thrill was appreciated in the right iliac fossa; no abdominal mass was clinically consistent with an abdominal aortic aneurysm. The patient was referred to color Doppler ultrasound examination that showed the existence of an arteriovenous fistula (AVF) between the right internal iliac artery and an enlarged right internal iliac vein. The computed tomography (CT) angiogram of abdomen confirms a voluminous ectasia of the right internal vein with a fistulous communication with the right internal iliac artery (Figure 1). Previous informed consent, the iliac vessels were exposed through a right extraperitoneal access under general anestesia. We observed a voluminous internal vein ectasia and a hypertrophic common and internal iliac artery. The internal iliac artery was clamped and has been performed a longitudinal arteriotomy. We found the AVF between the distal internal iliac artery and vein. The AVF was approximately 1 cm long and 5 mm wide. Bleeding from the AVF was controlled by digital compression. The fistula was closed directly using 4-0 prolene horizontal mattress stitches. Because of the persistence of thrill at the level of the iliac vein (for the likely presence of a more distal AVF) the ligation of the hypogastric artery and its branches of bifurcation was necessary, with subsequent remission of the thrill and reduction in the heart rate and the increase of diastolic blood pressure (signs of Nicoladoni-Branham).

caption.p: The right internal vein ectasia with a fistulous communication (CT scan).

body.p: The postoperative course was uneventful and the patient was discharged home on the fifth postoperative day.
